mn95:0.1_0: For the middle part of the night:
mn95:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Opāsāda.
mn95:1.3_0: He stayed in a sal grove to the north of Opāsāda called the “Gods’ Grove”.
mn95:10.1_0: Then Caṅkī together with a large group of brahmins went to the Buddha.
mn95:10.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
mn95:11.1_0: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting engaged in some polite conversation together with some very senior brahmins.
mn95:11.2_0: And the brahmin student Kāpaṭika was sitting in that assembly. He was young, newly tonsured; he was sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. He knew philogy and gramar, and was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
mn95:11.3_0: While the senior brahmins were conversing together with the Buddha, he interrupted.
mn95:11.5_0: “Venerable Bhāradvāja, don’t interrupt the senior brahmins.
mn95:11.7_0: When he had spoken, Caṅkī said to the Buddha,
mn95:11.8_0: “Master Gotama, don’t rebuke the student Kāpaṭika.
mn95:11.9_0: He’s a gentleman, learned, astute, a good speaker. He’s capable of having a dialogue with Master Gotama about this.”
mn95:12.11_0: “Master Gotama, regarding that which by the lineage of testament and by canonical authority is the ancient hymnal of the brahmins, the brahmins come to the definite conclusion:
mn95:12.12_0: ‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’
mn95:12.13_0: What does Master Gotama say about this?”
mn95:12.1_0: Then it occurred to the Buddha:
mn95:12.2_0: “Clearly the student Kāpaṭika will talk about the scriptural heritage of the three Vedas.
mn95:12.3_0: That’s why they put him at the front.”
mn95:12.5_0: “When the ascetic Gotama looks at me, I’ll ask him a question.”
mn95:12.6_0: Then the Buddha, knowing what Kāpaṭika was thinking, looked at him.
mn95:12.9_0: Why don’t I ask him a question?”
mn95:13.12_0: this is the only truth, other ideas are silly’?”
mn95:13.14_0: “So, Bhāradvāja, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins,
mn95:13.15_0: So it’s right to say this: ‘I know it or see it, I don’t know it.
mn95:13.16_0: this is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’
mn95:13.17_0: not even anyone back to the seventh generation of teachers,
mn95:13.18_0: So it’s right to say this: ‘I know it or see it, I don’t know it.
mn95:13.19_0: this is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’
mn95:13.1_0: “Well, Bhāradvāja, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this:
mn95:13.20_0: nor even the ancient hermits of the brahmins who say:
mn95:13.22_0: this is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’
mn95:13.23_0: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
mn95:13.24_0: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be like a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
mn95:13.26_0: This being so, doesn’t the brahmins’ faith turn out to be baseless?”
mn95:13.2_0: So it’s right to say this: ‘I know it or see it, I don’t know it.
mn95:13.3_0: this is the only truth, other ideas are silly’?”
mn95:13.5_0: “Well, is there even a single teacher of the brahmins, or a teacher’s teacher, or anyone back to the seventh generation of teachers, who says this:
mn95:13.6_0: So it’s right to say this: ‘I know it or see it, I don’t know it.
mn95:13.7_0: this is the only truth, other ideas are silly’?”
mn95:13.9_0: “Well, what of the ancient hermits of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
mn95:14.12_0: something may be well considered, it may be void, hollow, and false.
mn95:14.13_0: And even if you don’t have something well considered, it may be true and real, not otherwise.
mn95:14.14_0: For a sensible person who is preserving truth this is not sufficient to come to the definite conclusion:
mn95:14.15_0: ‘This is the only truth, other ideas are silly.’”
mn95:14.1_0: “The brahmins don’t just honor this because of faith, but also because of oral transmission.”
mn95:14.2_0: “First you relied on faith, now you speak of oral tradition.

mn95:17.1_0: “Bhāradvāja, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
mn95:17.2_0: A householder or their child approaches and scrutinizes them for three kinds of things:
mn95:17.3_0: things that arouse greed, things that provoke hate, and things that promote delusion.
mn95:17.4_0: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that arouse greed? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say
mn95:17.6_0: Which is for the lasting harm and suffering?
mn95:17.8_0: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that arouse greed.
mn95:18.10_0: This venerable teaches Dhamma that’s deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
mn95:18.11_0: It’s not easy for someone with hate to teach this.’
mn95:18.1_0: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that arouse greed. Next, they search them for qualities that provoke hate.
mn95:18.2_0: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that provoke hate? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say
mn95:18.4_0: Which is for the lasting harm and suffering?

mn95:18.8_0: Then, after death, they’re reborn in others for their lasting harm and suffering.
mn95:18.9_0: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without hate.

mn95:19.11_0: It’s not easy for someone with delusion to teach this.’

mn95:19.6_0: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that promote delusion.
mn95:19.8_0: Then, after death, they’re reborn in others for their lasting harm and suffering.
mn95:19.9_0: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without delusion.
mn95:2.1_0: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī was living in Opāsāda. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal endowment of the highest quality.
mn95:20.1_0: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that promote delusion.
mn95:20.2_0: they place faith in them. When faith has arisen they approach the teacher. They pay homage, lend an ear, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, reflect on their meaning, and accept them after consideration. Then enthusiasm springs up; they make an effort, weigh up, and persevere. Persevering, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.
mn95:20.3_0: That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the awakening to truth as defined in this way.
mn95:20.4_0: But this is not yet the arrival at the truth.”
mn95:21.1_0: “That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, Master Gotama. I regard the awakening to truth as defined in this way.
mn95:21.2_0: But Master Gotama, how do you define the arrival at the truth?”
mn95:21.3_0: I ask Master Gotama about the truth of the truth.”
mn95:21.4_0: “By the cultivation, development, and making much of these very same things there is the arrival at the truth.
mn95:21.5_0: That’s how the arrival at the truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the arrival at the truth as defined in this way.”
mn95:22.1_0: “That’s how the arrival at the truth is defined, Master Gotama. I regard the arrival at the truth as defined in this way.
mn95:22.2_0: But what quality is helpful for arriving at the truth?”
mn95:22.3_0: I ask the Master Gotama about the truth of the truth, and we ask Master Gotama about this.”
mn95:22.4_0: “Striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.
mn95:22.5_0: If you don’t strive, you won’t arrive at the truth.
mn95:22.6_0: You arrive at the truth because you strive.
mn95:22.7_0: That’s why striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.”
mn95:23.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:23.2_0: We’ve gained confidence in the teaching.”
mn95:23.3_0: “Weighing up the teachings is helpful for striving ...
mn95:23.4_0: If you don’t strive, you won’t strive.
mn95:23.5_0: But because you strive, you strive.
mn95:23.6_0: That’s why striving is helpful for striving.”
mn95:24.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:24.2_0: We’ll ask Master Gotama about this.”
mn95:24.3_0: Making an effort is helpful for weighing up the teachings ...
mn95:24.4_0: If you don’t think, you should lie down.
mn95:24.5_0: But since he is able to measure,
mn95:24.6_0: That’s why they’re plagued, and have no confidence.”
mn95:25.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:25.2_0: he’s gained much confidence in the Buddha and ask about the Teaching.”
mn95:25.3_0: Enthusiasm is helpful for making an effort ...
mn95:25.4_0: If you don’t get rid of desire, you shouldn’t consent to it.
mn95:25.6_0: That’s why a lot is helpful for enthusiasm.”
mn95:26.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for enthusiasm?”
mn95:26.2_0: I ask Master Gotama about his consent.”
mn95:26.3_0: Acceptance of the teachings after consideration is helpful for enthusiasm ...
mn95:26.4_0: If thoughts don’t grow, you shouldn’t consent to,
mn95:26.5_0: But since thoughts come up, they do grow.
mn95:26.6_0: That’s why they have helpful to acceptance after the teachings.”
mn95:27.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for accepting?”
mn95:27.2_0: We ask Master Gotama about the teachings, and we ask after accepting.”
mn95:27.3_0: Reflecting on the meaning of the teachings is helpful for accepting them after consideration ...
mn95:27.4_0: If they don’t examine the meaning, nor do they come to pass.
mn95:27.5_0: But since they reflect on the meaning of what they have remembered,
mn95:27.6_0: That’s why acceptance of the teachings is helpful for accepting them after consideration.”
mn95:28.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:28.2_0: I ask the ascetic Gotama about the meaning of the Teaching, and so many questions.”
mn95:28.3_0: Remembering the teachings is helpful for reflecting on their meaning ...
mn95:28.4_0: If you don’t understand the teaching, you should examine it,
mn95:28.5_0: But since you remember the teaching,
mn95:28.6_0: That’s why the teachings are helpful for reflecting on the meaning of the teaching.”
mn95:29.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:29.2_0: We ask Master Gotama about the teaching.”
mn95:29.3_0: Hearing the teachings is helpful for remembering the teachings ...
mn95:29.4_0: If you don’t listen to the teaching, you shouldn’t remember it.
mn95:29.5_0: But since they remember the teaching, they hear.
mn95:29.6_0: That’s why I listen to the teaching, a lot of Dhamma talk.”
mn95:3.1_0: The brahmins and householders of Opāsāda heard:
mn95:3.2_0: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the God’s Grove to the north.
mn95:3.4_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
mn95:3.5_0: With his own insight he has seen this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, and he makes it known to others.
mn95:3.6_0: They teach Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
mn95:3.7_0: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
mn95:30.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:30.2_0: I’ve questioned the teachings of Master Gotama.”
mn95:30.3_0: Listening is helpful for hearing the teachings ...
mn95:30.4_0: If you don’t listen to the teaching, you shouldn’t listen to the teachings.
mn95:30.5_0: But since he listens to the teaching,
mn95:30.6_0: That’s why a gift to listen to the teaching.”
mn95:31.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:31.2_0: We’ve asked Master Gotama about this matter.”
mn95:31.3_0: Paying homage is helpful for listening ...
mn95:31.4_0: If you don’t pay homage, you won’t listen.
mn95:31.5_0: But because you pay homage to him.
mn95:31.6_0: That’s why they’re very helpful to paying homage.”
mn95:32.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
mn95:32.2_0: We pay homage to Master Gotama.”
mn95:32.3_0: Approaching is helpful for paying homage ...
mn95:32.4_0: If you don’t approach, you wouldn’t pay homage to them.
mn95:32.5_0: You approach a teacher because you pay homage.
mn95:32.6_0: and pay homage to many people.”
mn95:33.1_0: “But what quality is helpful for approaching, Master Gotama?
mn95:33.2_0: We’ve approached Master Gotama, and I ask him about this.”
mn95:33.3_0: Faith is helpful for approaching a teacher.
mn95:33.4_0: If you don’t approach, you should go to them.
mn95:33.5_0: You approach a teacher because you have faith.
mn95:34.10_0: We like and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.
mn95:34.11_0: Master Gotama, I used to think this:
mn95:34.12_0: ‘Who are these shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman to be counted alongside those who understand the teaching?’
mn95:34.13_0: The Buddha has inspired me to have love, confidence, and respect for ascetics!
mn95:34.1_0: “I’ve asked Master Gotama about the preservation of truth, and he has answered me.
mn95:34.2_0: We like and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.
mn95:34.3_0: I’ve asked Master Gotama about awakening to the truth, and he has answered me.
mn95:34.4_0: We like and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.
mn95:34.5_0: I’ve asked Master Gotama about the arrival at the truth, and he has answered me.
mn95:34.6_0: We like and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.
mn95:34.7_0: I’ve asked Master Gotama about the things that are helpful for the arrival at the truth, and he has answered me.
mn95:34.8_0: We like and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.
mn95:34.9_0: Whatever I asked Master Gotama about, he has answered.
mn95:35.2_0: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
mn95:35.3_0: The fifth section on the heads is finished.
mn95:4.1_0: Then, having departed Opāsāda, they formed into companies and headed north to the God’s Grove.
mn95:5.1_0: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.
mn95:5.2_0: He saw the brahmins and householders heading for the God’s Grove,
mn95:5.4_0: “My steward, why are the brahmins and householders heading north for the God’s Grove?”
mn95:6.10_0: ‘Please go to see the ascetic Gotama; he’s going to see him.’”
mn95:6.1_0: “The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the God’s Grove to the north.
mn95:6.3_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
mn95:6.4_0: They’re going to see that Master Gotama.”
mn95:6.5_0: “Well then, go to the brahmins and householders
mn95:6.5_1: When they come to the brahmins and householders and say:
mn95:6.7_0: you to wait, as he will also go to see the ascetic Gotama.”
mn95:6.8_0: “Yes, sir,” replied the steward, and did as he was asked.
mn95:6.8_1: He went to the brahmins and householders and said,
mn95:7.1_0: Now at that time around five hundred brahmins from abroad were residing in Opāsāda on some business.
mn95:7.3_0: the brahmin Caṅkī was going to see the ascetic Gotama.
mn95:7.5_0: “Is it really true that you are going to see the ascetic Gotama?”
mn95:7.7_0: ‘I’ll go to see the ascetic Gotama.’”
mn95:8.10_0: You are ethical, mature in ethical conduct. ...
mn95:8.11_0: You’re a good speaker, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. ...
mn95:8.12_0: You teach the teachers of many, and teach three hundred students to recite the hymns. ...
mn95:8.13_0: You’re honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Pasenadi of Kosala
mn95:8.15_0: You live in Opāsāda, a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal endowment of the highest quality.
mn95:8.16_0: For all these reasons it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
mn95:8.17_0: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.”
mn95:8.2_0: It’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
mn95:8.3_0: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.
mn95:8.4_0: You are well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, irrefutable and impeccable in questions of ancestry back to the seventh paternal generation.
mn95:8.5_0: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
mn95:8.6_0: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.
mn95:8.8_0: You recite and remember the hymns, and have mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. You know philology and gramar, and are well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. ...
mn95:8.9_0: You are attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. You are magnificent, splendid, remarkable to behold. ...
mn95:9.10_0: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. He is magnificent, splendid, remarkable to behold. ...
mn95:9.11_0: He is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is noble and skillful. ...
mn95:9.12_0: The ascetic Gotama is a good speaker. ...
mn95:9.13_0: He is very helpful to many teachers. ...
mn95:9.14_0: He is rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for rebirth.
mn95:9.15_0: He teaches non-action about deeds and action, and he said to them:
mn95:9.16_0: He went forth from an eminent family of unbroken aristocratic lineage. ...
mn95:9.17_0: He went forth from a family of riches. ...
mn95:9.18_0: People come from distant lands and distant countries to question him. ...
mn95:9.19_0: The deities go for refuge to him. ...
mn95:9.1_0: When they had spoken, Caṅkī said to those brahmins:
mn95:9.21_0: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha. ...
mn95:9.22_0: The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks. ...
mn95:9.23_0: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. ...
mn95:9.24_0: King Pasenadi of Kosala and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. ...
mn95:9.25_0: The brahmin Pokkharasāti and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. ...
mn95:9.26_0: The ascetic Gotama has arrived to stay in the God’s Grove to the north of Opāsāda.
mn95:9.27_0: Any ascetic or brahmin who comes to stay in our village district is our guest,
mn95:9.28_0: and should be honored and respected as such.
mn95:9.29_0: The ascetic Gotama has arrived to stay in the God’s Grove to the north of Opāsāda.
mn95:9.2_0: “Well then, gentlemen, listen to why it’s appropriate for me to go to see the ascetic Gotama,
mn95:9.30_0: and should be honored and respected as such.
mn95:9.31_0: For this reason, too, it’s not appropriate for Master Gotama to come to see me,
mn95:9.32_0: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
mn95:9.33_0: This is the extent of Master Gotama’s praise that I have learned. But his praises are not confined to this,
mn95:9.34_0: for the praise of Master Gotama is limitless.
mn95:9.35_0: The possession of even a single one of these factors makes it inappropriate for Master Gotama to come to see me,
mn95:9.36_0: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
mn95:9.37_0: Well then, gentlemen, let’s all go to see the ascetic Gotama.”

mn95:9.7_0: When he went forth he abandoned abundant gold coin and bullion stored in dungeons and towers. ...
mn95:9.9_0: He shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness. ...
